attachments.title: "Oi" : The bike bell that doesn't look like a bike bell.
attachments.text: Bike bells generally look and sound a bit ugly. But why? What if they looked sexy and sounded like an angel playing a glockenspiel?
attachments.fallback: Kickstarter: "Oi" : The bike bell that doesn't look like a bike bell.

text: anyone  have a front light that they love? looking for a new one. mine’s not bright enough.
I don’t really. I’ve never spent the money to get a nice one. I take it you’re looking for one that’s “to see” and not one that’s “to be seen”?

I always get the standard CatEye front and back lights <http://www.amazon.com/Cateye-HL-EL135N-Bicycle-Head-Light/dp/B0041D0XFO> I like that they run on batteries. I like their level of brightness. And I like that they’re cheap so if they get stolen or something else happens they’re easy to replace.

text: and in my experience the best deal is always on Amazon
you’re free to check out mine on my desk. recharging through usb does suck sometimes, but it’s very very bright. got it at River City Bicycles or whatever that place is called

attachments.title: Amazon.com : Serfas Thunderbolt USB Taillight : Bike Taillights : Sports & Outdoors
attachments.text: <http://Amazon.com|Amazon.com> : Serfas Thunderbolt USB Taillight : Bike Taillights : Sports & Outdoors
attachments.fallback: Amazon.com : Serfas Thunderbolt USB Taillight : Bike Taillights : Sports & Outdoors

text: I have that taillight! I always forgot to charge it so I stopped using it..
What I like about them? Elastic bands allow for easy take-on, take-off and you can put them in areas not usually associated with bike lights, but that work much better (seat tube, stem)
i definitely want one that uses batteries. i will absolutely forget to charge them.
Also good price and pretty bright. As <@U0261PCRQ> mentioned, the cons are you have to charge them  pretty much every other night (or at work as I do) and you can lose the bands
